Fields.DialogueText: Cavour! You don't mind if I call you Cavour, do you?
"Conte di Cavour" a bit of a mouthful for you, Capitano?
A little bit, yes.
Don't look so concerned. Cavour is fine.
I'm glad to hear it. Listen...I've just received word from command that we're to transport some League of Nations committee members.
I wanted to let you know, so you weren't caught off guard.
What committee?

Fields.MenuText: You find this topic... interesting?
Is that information you need to have?
You have one of those faces where it's nearly impossible to tell what you're thinking. Do you know that?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. The League of Nations controls the Protection Force, after all. I prefer to keep myself aware of those in leadership over me. Now, answer the question, please.
I believe so. Now, please, answer the question.
Yes, and I'm proud of it. Now, please, answer the question.
The BWC– the Belle Welfare Committee. They're overseeing the well-being of the various Belles who've joined the Protection Force.
Is that a fact? Well, then, it looks as if I have some preparations to attend to.
Preparations? What does that mean?
*ALARM*
We should see to the battle, Capitano.
Her smile is more than a little unnerving...
@BATTLE
Capitano, do you have dossiers on the BWC members we'll be transporting?
Dossiers? I guess I do have some information on each of them. Why?
I'll need to borrow said information for a little while.

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind if I asked why?
This information isn't for public use, Cavour; I can't give it to just anyone.
You know, everything you say seems quite... calculated.

Fields.DialogueText: No, I don't mind.
And yet, these strangers will soon be walking all over me... using my rooms, eating in my mess hall. I'd figure it's the least you can do.
That's because it is, dear Capitano.
These people will be guests aboard my ship. The least I can do is receive them warmly and ensure that they are well cared for during their time aboard.
Reading their dossiers will help me better cater to them on an individual level.
That's very responsible of you, Cavour. And I wouldn't mind word getting back to the League that I captain one of the more welcoming ships in the fleet. Heh heh.
That blank stare of yours really doesn't do much for my self esteem, Cavour.
I would hope that your self esteem wouldn't live or die based on my opinion of your sense of humor.
*ALARM*
Shall we?
I think that would be best.
@BATTLE
You use guilt very effectively...
These are the goods I'll need before the BWC members arrive, Capitano.
There is a lot of wine and cheese on this list, Cavour. What makes you think the Protection Force will pay for these items?
By and large, it appears that this committee is made up of some very powerful individuals.
And considering the committee members work for the League, the organization which controls the Protection Force, I'd wager the Force wouldn't bat an eye at covering the cost.

Fields.MenuText: That's sound logic you've employed, Cavour.
It's a shame the Force would bow to a few self-important individuals...
In that case, we should order a little extra and keep it for ourselves.

Fields.DialogueText: It's the only kind of logic I dare tolerate.
Such is the world we live in, I'm afraid.
Rest assured, I've arranged for more than a few spare bottles.
You seem quite adept at this business, Cavour.
An apt choice of words, dear Capitano.
Which word? Business?
Captain, we have Morganas approaching from the south.
We'll be there shortly. Thank you.
Cavour, wait! We are going to talk about this! Cavour!
@BATTLE
Cavour! I still need to speak with you!
You know, you make it difficult for me to prepare for the committee members' arrival with these constant distractions.
I am your captain. I hope you would consider my wanting to speak with you more than a mere distraction.
Very well, then. Speak your mind.
... Just like that?
You appealed to me on logical grounds, and I accept your reasoning. Please understand, I am still accustoming myself to being under your command.

Fields.MenuText: I... suppose that is understandable.
I hope you know, I am doing my best to look out for your well-being.
Overly logical people kind of freak me out, Cavour.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for your understanding.
I trust that, as I come to know you better, that will become even more apparent to me.
And yet you were made a capitano. How strange this world is, at times.
All I wanted to ask was what you meant earlier, when you said you looking after the committee members was business.
Ah, I see. Believe me, Capitano, my concern for the BWC does not stem from some intrinsic need to care for guests aboard this ship.
It doesn't?
Of course not. This is politics, my business. If I give them proper care, their opinion of me will rise. And you should never underestimate the good opinion of powerful people.
I'm... glad you're on my side. You're on my side, right?
Yes, dear Capitano. I am on your side.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I must say, Cavour, I've scarcely seen so many powerful people look so happy aboard a ship. The BWC members really do seem to appreciate the lengths you've gone to.
It does appear that way, does it not?
Signorina Cavour? May I speak to you for a moment?
There is no need for such a formal address. Cavour will work fine.
Goodness, you are very tall. The tallest Belle we've met since the committee formed, I think!
Excuse me, I don't think we met before. Are you one of the committee members?
Oh, no, my apologies, Capitano.
Capitano, this is Elena Sartini, assistant to Felix Mercier, the head of the BWC.
Ah, I see, my mistake. Welcome aboard, Elena.
Thank you, Capitano. Cavour, there is a very specific type of facial wipe Signor Mercier prefers to use while traveling...
He'll find them stored next to his bed.
Splendid. Thank you so much, Cavour– you really did plan for everything.
It seems you're well on your way to finding yourself in the good opinion of powerful people, Cavour.
Believe me, there is much more work to be done, Capitano.
*ALARM*
I'm sure it will go a long way for their estimation of you.
It will, won't it?
@BATTLE
Mademoiselle Cavour, this food is entirely too delicious. Tell me, does the entire crew aboard this ship eat as well as we have in our time here?
The crew is adequately cared for, I assure you. But for guests such as yourselves, I brought in a special cook, to prepare meals just for you.
I thought as much. If the crew ate like this day in and day out, I imagine there wouldn't be much use for them in battle!
*LAUGHTER*

Fields.MenuText: This group can seem a little... grating, after a while.
Wealthy people will be the death of me one day, I'm sure.
I ought to use these idiots as ammo, next Morgana we come across.

Fields.DialogueText: Grating they may be, but the work they do is for the good of the Belles. Don't forget that.
You fear no Morgana, and yet you fear the wealthy? How strange, Capitano.
Now, now, there's no reason to be quite so surly, Capitano.
We can't thank you enough for your hospitality, Mademoiselle. You've made the start of our voyage very enjoyable, indeed.
It's been my pleasure. Tell me, I'm curious...how many more members of the BWC are there?
More members? I'm not sure what you mean. The whole of the Belle Welfare Committee is represented here, at this table.
Cavour? Did you... break? I've never seen you speechl–
There are no... Belles, on the Belle Welfare Committee?
Belles? Belles on a League of Nations committee? Well, that is an adorable idea, Cavour. No, the committee is made up entirely of those you see here.
*ALARM*
Cavour? Are you going to... you know... move?
... I'm coming.
@BATTLE
Officers, to your stations! There is a raid going on, we must defeat these Morganas!
@BATTLE
Wow, Cavour, I've never seen you quite so focused, in battle. That was really – really – something else.
You know, you've seemed a little more... uh...
Actually, now that I think about it, your moods generally defy conventional adjectives. But, you have seemed more... something... than usual.

Fields.MenuText: Care to share what's going on?
While your battle performance has been admirable, I want to ensure that you're all right.
I can play the silent game too, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Not particularly.
As if it would matter to you.
I am trying to help, Cavour.
Are you? Because I don't think it would take much thought to determine why I'm displeased, at the current moment. Try using your head.
Moody. Yeah, moody was definitely the adjective I was looking for. Which is ridiculous. It's not like it's all that complex of a word...
All right, Cavour, honestly, I've been doing my best to identify why you're upset.
And what conclusions have you drawn?
It was that meal, the meal with the BWC. I mean, I know that's when you first started acting odd.
Oh, good grief. You really are quite the detective, aren't you?
Hold on, I'm getting there. You asked about the BWC's membership, if any Belles were part of the committee.
And when Felix replied, he did so about as patronizingly as a person could. I'd be angry with him too, if he's spoke to me that way.
No.

Fields.MenuText: No? No, what?
I'd prefer a "Capitano" on the end of the sentence, you know.
You know, I really tried here. Doesn't that get me anywhere?

Fields.DialogueText: That isn't why I'm upset.
Fine. No, Capitano. Are you pleased?
Hardly.
The man has been patronizing me since he stepped foot on my ship. It takes more than a little condescension to rile me.
Then why are you upset?
Because there are no Belles on the Belle Welfare Committee! We're supposed to blindly trust that humankind has our best interests at heart?
Do we have any guarantee that we'll never be taken advantage of? That we're not just objects with which to win a war to them?
By no means. At least one Belle should be a required presence on the committee, to ensure that our needs are being properly represented.
I... yeah. That... that would make sense.
Thank you!
There are some Morganas out on the horizon, there. You could pretend every one of them is Felix Mercier.
It would be a diverting way to pass the time, wouldn't it?
@BATTLE
Good day, Capitano.
Cavour.
Wait.
Hmm? Did you say something?
I see that.
You see what?
I see that gleam in your eye. That same gleam I saw when you first heard the BWC was coming aboard this ship.
The gleam that, I assume, accompanied your plan at getting in their good graces.
Well, well, Capitano. It appears you are capable of deducing some things at some times.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, occasionally, I am.
You know, Felix Mercier isn't the only patronizing person aboard this ship.
I can deduce that you're a bit of an ass at all times.

Fields.DialogueText: You may prove to be of use to me yet.
Tsk, did I strike a nerve, dear Capitano?
Was that something approaching wit, I just heard? Capitano, I didn't know you were capable.
Tell me, what are you up to?
Since there's no Belle on the Belle Welfare Committee, I believe it's only right that I try for a position on the committee myself.
Really? You're going to find a way onto a League of Nations committee? That will... certainly be unprecedented.
There is first for everything in life, Capitano. I will not let this opportunity pass me by.
*ALARM*
Think it will wait until after this battle?
Oh, Capitano. You think you're so clever.
@BATTLE
Monsieur Mercier! I've been looking for you.
Ah, Mademoiselle Cavour! I've been looking for you as well, believe it or not. I just sent Elena to find you, but you have found me first!
I have a matter of business, which I'd like to discuss with you.
Of course, of course, dear girl. But first, I was wondering if you might see to something.
What do you need?
I'm afraid I have completely finished off that scrumptious wine you set out for me in my room.
... All of it?
Yes. I was hoping you could run to your wine stores and fetch some more for me. What do you say?
Cavour! Monsieur Mercier, excuse my intrusion, but I need to speak to Cavour. It's official fleet business. You understand.
And don't worry, Monsieur. I'll have your wine to you before you know it.
My deepest thanks. See you soon, Mademoiselle!
Cavour? I apologize for stepping in, but I was passing by, and noticed your face was a very noticeable shade of red. I wanted to avoid you assaulting Felix, if possible.
Even if I suspect he certainly would've had it coming.
I was under control, Capitano, although I appreciate your concern. Sometimes, it just takes a little longer for me to swallow my rage than it does normally.
As you're well aware, that wine was not inexpensive. To have finished it off this quickly shows a level of irresponsibility unacceptable in those in power.
I can't say I disagree with you on any particular point.
*ALARM*
Do we really have more of the wine? Will you be able to track it down after the battle?
Yes, Capitano. I'm always prepared.
@BATTLE
There you are, Cavour. Have you been able to ask Felix about a position with the BWC?
Not yet. Much of the committee has found themselves in need of one luxury item or another, and I've had my hands full trying to accommodate all of them.
And yet, every time I pass by one of them, they appear as pleased as the day they arrived. You take excellent care of them, in spite of your frustration.
I know that I cannot let present irritations affect me; not if I wish to see my plans come to fruition. Showing my anger would do nothing to help the situation.

Fields.MenuText: True enough.
I admire your restraint.
Still, the mental image of you ripping their heads off – figuratively or otherwise – is quite entertaining.

Fields.DialogueText: I will let my rational mind succeed over emotion in every situation.
It requires great discipline, I must admit.
It would be quite... cathartic.
Well, I'm rooting for you, Cavour. And if there's anything I can do to help you succeed, just let me know.
Your consideration is kind, Capitano. Thank you. Now, I do think there are Morganas approaching from the northwest.
We'd best see to it, then.
@BATTLE
Capitano, I see Morganas on our path.
All right, crew, you heard the Belle! Man your stations – we have work to do here!
@BATTLE
Don't look now, but your favorite committee leader is headed this way...
Mademoiselle Cavour!
I really must thank you for all you've done for the committee thus far. I have half a mind to take you with us, wherever we go.
Once we've left your ship, I imagine we won't know what to do without you.
... Is that a fact?
Undoubtedly! Without you by our side, it will be as if we're adrift at sea.
In that case, I have a matter of business to discuss with you.
Do you, now? And look at how very serious your face is, dear! I must say, I am all ears.
I am of the mind that a Belle should be a part of your committee.
Only a Belle could fully understand what it is like to be a Belle, especially in regard to the struggles we face in battle.
And since I have proven to you and your committee that I am a capable and competent being, worthy of your trust, I would like to submit my name for the position.
Ho, ho! Well, this is delightful. Most diverting, Mademoiselle.
Diverting?
Yes, quite. I appreciate your concern, but trust me...the committee is more than capable of looking after you and your sisters. You have nothing to worry your pretty head over.
Now, I must be on my way; I'm late to a game of cards!
Unbelievable.
Felix, man. What. An. Ass.
I can't say I disagree with you, Capitano.
To speak to you in such a condescending way? If anyone ever spoke to me like that...
Actually, you speak to me like that, sometimes.
Please tell me I'm not quite that terrible.
I've never felt like punching you square in your jaw. But him? Ooohh... it was a close one. You know, it's not too late. I can push him overboard, if you like.
That won't be necessary, Capitano. I do not consider this matter closed.
Felix doesn't seem the type to change his mind willingly.
"Willingly" is the key word in that statement, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: Just what are you planning now?
Should I start filling out an incident report now, or should I wait until later?
Are you planning for something for which tickets could be sold? Because the crew's been itching for a fight, and I could use some walking-around money.

Fields.DialogueText: As if I'm ever not planning.
My plans don't call for an incident report at this moment, but I'll let you know the moment that changes.
I'm sorry to disappoint you, Capitano, but my plans involve a little more elegance than what accompanies a mere fistfight.
Captain! Morganas have been spotted!
We'll be there shortly.
@BATTLE
Morganas approaching! We have a chance to get the jump on them. We have to take it!
@BATTLE
You seemed a little less focused in that last battle, Cavour.
I'm in the midst of planning, Capitano. Please excuse me.
Just don't tune the battles out completely.
I'm too fond of the land of the living to endanger myself in such a way, Capitano. Rest assured, I won't leave you in the lurch.
And how is your planning coming?
I know what I would like to do... I just need to find the means to do it.
And what is it, exactly?
Blackmail, preferably.

Fields.MenuText: B-Blackmail?
Yeah, I'd better go start that incident report after all...
Oh, this is even better than a fight!

Fields.DialogueText: So simple, yet so effective.
Calm yourself. I told you, I'll let you know the moment an incident report becomes necessary.
You are amused by the strangest things, Capitano.
So, you want to blackmail Felix into giving you a position on the committee, but you don't have the means to do so. How are you planning on finding said means?
I'm not sure yet. Observation is key, in matters such as these. But a man as powerful and wealthy as Felix... I'm sure he has something hidden, something I could use against him.
...You have this under control, right?
Dear Capitano, I am always in control.
I can't believe you sit through all of these BWC meetings, Cavour. They're about as dull as they come.
Maybe so. But as the war drags on, there will be more and more need for a committee such as this one.
Besides, the more time I spend around Felix, the stronger the possibility I find something I could use against him.
If you say so.
Wait! Did you see that?

Fields.MenuText: I most certainly did not.
I see that cobweb up in the corner of the room. Some sailor is going to get an earful from me.
You're gripping my arm a little too tightly there, Cavour. My hand would appreciate circulation.

Fields.DialogueText: That's what you get for not paying attention.
That's what you notice?
Oh. My apologies, Capitano.
What did you see?
Just as Felix had finished speaking, Elena, his assistant, rolled her eyes.
How is that groundbreaking behavior? I roll my eyes every time the man's in my general vicinity.
Yes, but you're not the man's assistant. If anyone were to know where Felix keeps his skeletons buried, it would be Elena.
And if she finds him as irritating as we do, then there's a reasonably good chance that we'll be able to convince her to tell us something damaging about her boss.
It's a little frightening, how quickly you were able to put that together.
*ALARM*
We have a battle to see to, Capitano. But once we're done, well... that's when the real fun begins.
@BATTLE
Elena! There you are, I've been looking for you.
Have you, Cavour? Did Signor Mercier ask for something? I'm not aware of his needing anything, at the moment.
No, no – I wanted to know how you're doing. The work you're doing, it can't be for the faint of heart, I'm sure.
Constantly on the move, forever at the beck and call of someone as... well... how would you describe the Monsieur?
... Exacting?
Yes, he is very demanding, isn't he? Believe me, I can relate.
You... can? You mean, the Capitano?
Makes demands left and right, keeps me up at all hours, constantly forces a stomach-churning sense of humor upon me... it's thankless work, really.
Goodness, I had no idea. You really do understand, don't you?
I do, I do. You know, I couldn't help, but notice you roll your eyes at the Monsieur during the BWC's last meeting.
...You did?
Yes, when the Monsieur was speaking on the importance of integrity, of all things. Why did you feel the need to roll your eyes at that moment?
Oh! Uh... no, for no reason in particular. I might have just had something in my eye, that's all.
My mistake, Elena. But, I want you to know that, if there's ever anything you'd like to talk about, I'm here for you.
Th-thank you, Cavour.
Stomach-churning sense of humor? Really?
Of the things I listed, that's what you took issue with?

Fields.MenuText: ... Is my humor really that revolting?
When I gave you permission to exaggerate the work I have you do, I wasn't expecting you to detail the work with such relish.
At least I have a sense of humor.

Fields.DialogueText: Not really, no. But like I told you earlier, you really ought not base your self esteem on my opinion of your sense of humor.
I had to sell it, Capitano. Surely you can understand.
Your defensiveness tells me it's not a sense in which you have much confidence.
You really think Elena will tell you what she knows?
In all honesty, I have no idea. But we'll see, won't we?
*ALARM*
Let's go.
@BATTLE
In all honestly, I've felt my confidence waning since the moment I stepped foot on this ship...
You know, I feel as if, during these BWC meetings, you and I constitute the peanut gallery. In more than one sense.
You're just saying that because I actually brought peanuts with me today.
I mean, they are what made me think of it. Are those honey roasted?
I bartered for them last time we were at dock.
You want some, don't you?
Yes, please.
Here, you can have the rest.
You sure?
Shush.
What?
Hush!
Elena, I thought I told you to bring the documents from last month's inspections to today's meeting.
My apologies, Signor, but I only heard you ask for the past two weeks' worth.
Only the past two weeks' worth? Well, that is preposterous. That's what I get for hiring an Italian, I suppose. Heh.
Oh, he's the worst.
Yes, but do you see that gleam in Elena's eyes?
It's a gleam I've come to recognize on sight.
Monsieur Felix might have just done us a sizeable favor. Now, come Capitano. There are Morganas headed toward us, and we need to give Elena time to process her fury.
@BATTLE
What is that in the dis... Oh. Officers, get ready for battle!
@BATTLE
Cavour? That was an impressive battle.
I appreciate the compliment, Elena. How are you? I heard Monsieur Mercier's tasteless comment earlier. It really was abominable of him.
It's... far from the first he's made.
You have my sympathy, having to work for such a man. If there was something I could do to save you from such work, I would.
Elena?
I... well. I really... I don't know.
Say what you need to say, Elena. You'll feel better once you do.
I have some... information on the Monsieur, information which could be used... to oust him from his current position. But I'm not sure... I don't know...
I would have no qualms using it for you, Elena.
You... you wouldn't?
No, matters such as these do not bother me. If it would save you grief, then I would be happy to lend a hand.
I would have to send for the information; my brother has it hidden away. You don't mind waiting?
No, I would prefer to see it with my own eyes. Have your brother make copies, and send those to us at once.
... All right. I'll do it.
Your ability to play that girl, Cavour... it's a little disturbing. Honestly.
Such is the world of politics, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: You do know the line between what's right and wrong, right?
More and more, I understand why I prefer to exist outside of that world.
Remind me to have you teach me a few of your tricks, someday.

Fields.DialogueText: I know the line I will not cross. Whether or not that line correlates with yours is an entirely different matter.
Capitano, you can remain ignorant regarding the world of politics if you so choose, but it is impossible to extricate yourself from that world. Its influence will always be upon you.
Ah, I would be happy to do so, Capitano.
Still waiting on Elena's information to arrive?
Still waiting. You're well aware of how long it takes correspondence to arrive.
What are the chances the Protection Force realizes how incriminating said correspondence is? They might go to extreme lengths to protect someone as powerful as Felix.
Elena assured me that the information is innocuous enough in appearance. With any luck, it will float right on by.
Has Elena given you any hint as to how the information incriminates Felix? Just what is it that he's done?
You sound as if you've been considering certain possibilities.

Fields.MenuText: He could be in cahoots with the Morganas.
He could be having a torrid affair with Rachele Mussolini.
He could be a German spy.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know that you really understand how the Morganas work, Capitano.
Were that the case, the Morganas would be the least of his worries.
If so, he's one of the best actors this world has ever produced.
So, what do you think he's done?
Such wealth in the hands of one so profligate... the problem is almost certainly financial.
That's considerably less exciting.
Yes, well, it is the way of things.
*ALARM*
This might be more exciting.
Doubtful. After a while, all of these battles seem to meld together.
@BATTLE
C-Cavour?
Are you all right, Elena? This morning's battle didn't rattle you too badly, did it?
You do look a little pale.
No, no, it's nothing like that. The, um... box arrived.
Ah, I see. Everything is in there, then?
It should be.
Don't worry, Elena. I'll take care of everything from here.
A-all right.

Fields.MenuText: She certainly trusts you, to entrust you with this information, Cavour.
She isn't the most courageous girl.
Pop open that box! I want to see what's inside.

Fields.DialogueText: I have a feeling this has less to do with trust, and more to do with desperation. Do remember who she works for.
Her position gives her little power. She is right to be wary.
Patience, Capitano.
Judging by the box's weight, there will be much for me to sort through.
Well, then, I'll leave you to it.
*ALARM*
I doubt that makes much difference right now.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
*KNOCK*
*KNOCK*
You may enter, Capitano.
While I understand your desire for caution, Cavour, don't you think secret knock sequences go, maybe, a little too far?
No.

Fields.MenuText: Oh. Well... all right, then.
As captain of this ship, it seems... a little silly.
Well, then, maybe we should go all out. Add in a little syncopation, or something like that.

Fields.DialogueText: So easily you give up your position, Capitano. What a shame.
Better a little silliness than Felix walking in before I've had the opportunity to hide this evidence.
If a little syncopation would make you happy, Capitano, then by all means, have at it.
Was there anything useful in the box? That's quite the stack of papers you have there.
It will take some more time for me to sort through everything. There are a lot of receipts here, and they're not all in the best of handwriting.
But based on what I'm seeing, I think there is information here I could use to my advantage.
*ALARM*
Blast.
You want me to help you put the evidence away before battle?
Yes, please. Thank you, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Cavour! It looks as if we have a few Morganas headed this way...
Quiet. You're coming with me.
Doesn't look as if I have much of a choice in the matter.
I don't need what I'm about to tell you to circulate amongst the crew.
All right, all right. There's no one over here. What's up?
I finished sorting through those receipts.
Aha. And what did you find?
For the past several years, Felix and another Frenchman with the League of Nations, one Maurice Dubois, have...
Well, let's just say they haven't been properly caring for the League's finances.

Fields.MenuText: And you have evidence of this? Solid evidence?
I always knew the man was scum.
So it wasn't a torrid affair? What a disappointment...

Fields.DialogueText: The solidest.
It was an opinion held by most of us on board, Capitano.
I know, I know, you were hoping for something a little more dramatic.
And what about the other man? Dubois?
Well, therein lies a more complicated factor. Maurice Dubois is Felix's superior, and holds a position of prestige within the League.
I must take him into account when deciding what to do with the information I have. I know Elena is hoping I'll use it to oust Felix, but... well, we'll see.
All right, all right. We have to get to our stations, Cavour, but keep me updated, understand?
Yes, Captain.
@BATTLE
They're onto us! Quick, fire at will!
@BATTLE
Cavour! I saw Elena just before the battle; she said you had drafted a letter to the League.
I was just coming to find you. The letter will be sent to the President of the Assembly himself.
So you decided against blackmail, then? You're just hoping the League fires Felix, essentially. That's no guarantee of a spot on the committee for yourself, you realize?
Well... the nature of Felix's indiscretions altered my plans, I will admit. But I dare say that I have even greater hopes for this course of action.
That's good to hear, I guess. How long do you think it will take for your letter to have an effect?
There's no telling, honestly. But the League is protective of their finances, I'm sure, and won't look kindly on the offending party, as a result.
Oh, Mademoiselle Cavour! I'm in need of your assistance!
I guess, until then, we just put up with him as best we can?
That's the idea.
I'm coming, Monsieur!
Cavour...
What is it, Capitano?
Elena is locked inside her quarters, and refuses to speak with anyone. Would you know why?
Ah, Capitaine! There you are. I've been looking for you.
Monsieur Mercier. You look even more chipper than usual.
Yes, well, this is all very bittersweet. You see, I will soon be leaving your fine vessel.
You will?
Indeed. The League has tapped me to fill an opening left by my disgraced former friend, Maurice Dubois. But I won't bore you with the details.
The rest of the BWC will continue their work aboard your ship, lead by the ever capable Belle on board, Mademoiselle Cavour.
What.
You heard the man, Capitano. Monsieur Mercier generously gave the League my name when asked for input on his replacement. I will be leading the committee from now on.
Are my bags packed, Mademoiselle?
You will find them ready in your quarters.
Splendid. Capitaine, it's been a pleasure.

Fields.MenuText: What did you do?
How could you do... whatever you did... to Elena?
This is a scheme of yours, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll tell you once the Monsieur has disembarked.
One must think about the future, not just the present moment, Capitano.
Naturally.
*ALARM*
I do want an explanation.
I will have one for you and Elena both.
@BATTLE
Unsurprisingly, Cavour, Elena isn't very pleased with you. She assumed you would use her information to oust Felix from his position.
I did, in a manner of speaking.
Forgive me if I was hoping for an ousting more unfortunate than a promotion.
I have to say, I understand her frustration, Cavour.
So, tell me, Elena. I use the evidence you gave me to have the League fire Felix. You have your revenge.
But then, what? The BWC is a necessary committee. Who would the League have replace him?
...No one you'd like.
Mmhmm. And what future advantage would such an ousting give us?
What?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah... what?
Again, this is why I don't like politics.
Ah, now I see where this is going.

Fields.DialogueText: Pay attention.
Dislike it if you wish.
Do you? I'm proud of you, Capitano.
I only gave the League the information incriminating Maurice Dubois. And Felix is aware of the rest of the information I hold.
...He is?
Of course. Why else would he have recommended me for his position?
Ah... yes.
And that is information I will hold over his head for as long as necessary.
If I deem it necessary to ascend the ranks of the League, you can be sure I will have his support.
You realize how shady all of what you've done is, right?
I've never made myself out to be a paragon of virtue, Capitano. But I will always protect the Belles, and if that means taking advantage of certain situations?
Well, then, I'll do it.
And I would do the same to protect you.
Now, there are some Morganas headed this way. I would suggest that have the crew sound the alarm.

Fields.MenuText: Whew... keeping up with her isn't going to be easy.
I've never been so floored by a person in my life.
